div1.p: Kelly solicits corrections or clarifications for a new edition of his book, “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever.“

div1.head: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to William H. Welch, October 7, 1922
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
HOWARD A. KELLY, M. D.
LIBRARY
1406 EUTAW PLACE, BALTIMORE, MD.
CABLE ADDRESS, “HAKELY,” BALTIMORE
October 7, 1922.
Saturday
Dear Doctor Welch:
div1.p:
I am revising my life of
Walter Reed for a new edition, adding memoranda
about Sternberg and a chapter on Gorgas, and
I find a contradiction between Gorgas' state-
ment and my own on Reed's life. I think Gorgas
must be correct.

My statement is that Lazear,
while attending a patient in the yellow fever
ward of Las Animas Hospital, allowed a mosquito
to bite him which he mistook for a “common, ordinary,
brown mosquito.” Gorgas says that Lazear knew that
the mosquito was a stegomyia and that he simply
took his chances in the matter. I do not know
now where I got my first impression. I think we
all felt sure that Lazear was well aware of the
risk he was taking. If you will indicate briefly
your feelingmemory in the matter, I shall make the
correction accordingly.
